steps.title: Cleanse the wound.
steps.content: Cleanse the wound. Depending on the condition of the healed incision, use sterile saline solution , an antiseptic such as alcohol, or sterile swabs to remove any debris or dried fluids from the wound. [2] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source

steps.title: Slide the lower part of a staple remover under the middle of the staple.
steps.content: Slide the lower part of a staple remover under the middle of the staple. Begin at one end of the healed incision. [3] X Research source This is a specialized tool doctors use to take out surgical staples. The lower part of the stapler usually has 2 teeth and is flatter than the upper part, which moves.

steps.title: Squeeze the handles of the staple remover until they are completely closed.
steps.content: Squeeze the handles of the staple remover until they are completely closed. The upper part of the staple remover will push down the middle of the staple, causing the staple ends to pull out of the incision. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Take out the staple by releasing the pressure on the handles.
steps.content: Take out the staple by releasing the pressure on the handles. When the staples are removed, drop them into a disposable container or bag. [5] X Research source Pull out the medical staple in the same direction it went in to avoid tearing your skin. You might feel a slight pinch, sting, or tugging sensation. This is normal. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Use the staple remover to remove all the other staples.
steps.content: Use the staple remover to remove all the other staples. [7] X Research source When the end of the incision is reached, inspect the area again to check for any staples that may have been missed. This will help to prevent future skin irritation and infection.

steps.title: Cleanse the wound with antiseptic again.
steps.content: Cleanse the wound with antiseptic again. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Apply a dry dressing or bandage if needed.
steps.content: Apply a dry dressing or bandage if needed. The type of covering applied depends on how well the wound has healed. [9] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source Use a butterfly bandage or Steri-Strip if there is still skin separation. This will provide support and help to prevent the formation of a larger scar. Use a light gauze dressing to prevent irritation. This will act as a buffer between the affected area and your clothing. Expose the healing incision to the air, if possible. Make sure not to cover the affected area with clothing, to avoid irritation.

steps.title: Watch for signs of infection.
steps.content: Watch for signs of infection. The redness around the closed incision should fade over a few weeks. Follow your doctor's advice on wound care, and be aware of the following signs of infection: [10] X Trustworthy Source Johns Hopkins Medicine Official resource database of the world-leading Johns Hopkins Hospital Go to source Redness and irritation around the affected area. Affected area is hot to the touch. Increased pain. Yellow or green discharge. Fever.
